tabs.header_iregular:
Let's see what is available over-the-counter for vertigo.

Medicines available over-the-counter are to help reduce the dizziness and nausea associated with vertigo.

This will assume you are seeing a physician for this vertigo and just want to know what to take over the counter to help with the associated nausea and dizziness.

If this is the case, options available over the counter are listed below.

collapsable.title: Antihistamine click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Some cases of vertigo may not require treatment, but others may respond to over-the-counter antihistamines.

Meclizine, dimenhydrinate  and  diphenhydramine are the main over the counter antihistamines that will help with nausea and dizziness associated with vertigo.

Prefer something with meclizine 25 mg over the others.

collapsable.title: Natural remedies click to expand contents
collapsable.content: Natural medicines that may help some people include  ginger root, ginkgo biloba, and coriander.

collapsable.title: Vitamin D click to expand contents
collapsable.content: This can help in some people if you have been diagnosed as having vitamin D deficiency.

irregular.content: Last updated by pharmacist on : 02/16/2016 at 10:50:am

  • The pharmacist image presented in this article may or may not be the actual image of the authoring pharmacist.
    Because we insist on using articles written by currently practicing community pharmacists, these pharmacists may choose to remain anonymous especially if they are employed by an employer to avoid being pressured to recommend a particular product to drive sales.

What if you are currently experiencing the conditions listed below?

Or if you have a question for the pharmacist?

collapsable.title: You have a question click to expand contents
collapsable.content: Please contact the pharmacist. He or she will gladly answer your questions.

collapsable.title: Contacting the pharmacist click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
You may have to unlock the contact form using social networking tools (facebook, twitter, google+, linkedIn) we have made available to you.

If you can't do this, you will have to wait a few seconds depending on the number of users at the time.

collapsable.title: What to expect click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Expect a reply as soon as possible.
If the authoring pharmacist cannot reply within 24 hours, the system will push your email to the rest of the team. Any available pharmacist will answer your question as soon as possible.

If you have a comment and not a question, please post it in the comments section for all to read.

collapsable.title: What can't be done: click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
No replies to vulgar, disrespectful emails.
The system is programmed to look for certain words that are disrespectful and will automatically delete such emails. They don't get to the pharmacist. This will blacklist your email address automatically.

Email addresses or questions are not saved.
They are deleted once answered and not stored in a database. Should you need to follow up, copy the previous question(s) along with the new message for quick reference.

The pharmacist does not reply to emails that are not relevant to the topic he or she authored. They are forwarded to the author of the topic and are under no obligation to reply.

We encourage pharmacists to respond to questions but are under no obligations to answer questions.

tabs.header_iregular:
Let's figure out what will give you relief from this toothache.

The goal of this recommendation is to see what you can use over the counter for toothache until you can see a dentist.

With toothache, you will have to see a dentist. The more you delay, the worse it will get.

You should try these in the order listed.

collapsable.title: 1. Salt water rinse click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Place 2 to 3 teaspoonful of table salt in a glass of warm water you can tolerate.

Swiss and spit as a mouth wash for about 30 seconds as needed.

collapsable.title: 2. Pain pills click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
NonSteroidal Anti-inflammatory Drugs (NSAIDS)

such as ibuprofen or naproxen would help with the inflammation, pain and swelling.

If you can't take NSAIDs, acetaminophen would be a second choice.

But don't take acetaminophen as a first choice. It is not very good with the inflammatory pain associated with a toothache.

collapsable.title: 3a. Eugenol (clove oil) click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Use a Q-tip to apply clove oil to the toothache.​

Place a little folded gauze pad to prevent it from being washed away for maximum effect.

Can't find clove oil?

Look for preparations in the dental aisle containing eugenol. (Red Cross Toothache®, DenTek®).

This is the pain relieving ingredient in clove oil.

If clove oil (eugenol) is not your thing, then go with benzocaine.

collapsable.title: 3b. Benzocaine click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Preparations containing 20% benzocaine will help numb the toothache pain for a few hours.

Know that the numbing agent will eventually wash away.

How long depends on the amount of saliva you are producing. So make sure you combine this with something like ibuprofen. 

Average relief time is 4 hours.

Remember, it is clove oil (eugenol) or 20% benzocaine. Not both.

collapsable.title: 4. Cold compress click to expand contents
collapsable.content: If swollen and very painful, press an ice pack against the cheek closest to the toothache for about 5 to 10 minutes 3 to 4 times a day to alleviate the pain.

collapsable.title: Worth mentioning click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Massaging the web of the hand between the thumb and index finger on the same side as the body with the toothache pain with ice has been found to produce up to a 50% reduction in acute dental pain [ R. Melzack et ].

I haven't tried it yet, but it would be interesting to see the result the next time I have a toothache.

If you tried it, please post your experience in the comments section.

irregular.content: Last updated by pharmacist on : 02/16/2016 at 10:50:am

tabs.header_iregular:
Without treatment, cold sore should heal within 2 weeks.

Depending on how bad it is, we can use over the counter medications to take care of this.

But know that there is no cure for it.

Once you get it, it stays in your body.

It is important to know what the triggers are and cut down on how often they appear. 

But if your cold sore comes on frequently, we recommend you see a doctor not only to treat the cold sore but to also get a prescription medication like valcyclovir for suppression.

Let's take a look at what is available over the counter to help with the symptoms of a  cold sore and use this information to manage this cold sore effectively.
tabs.header:
Which of the symptoms listed below are you experiencing right now?

Choose the nature of this cold sore from the list below and see what you can use over-the-counter.
fieldset: At the tingling or prodrome stage
Small blisters grew together to form a large blister.
Sore is red, raised a little.

mode.1:
None of these?
We must have left something out.

If you think you have a flu:

Please go back and choose the symptom(s) that you feel closely relate to what you have or might have had and let's recommend something for you.

Remember, there is no cure for the flu. All we can do is manage the symptoms if you have one.
mode.2: Something to prevent or boost your resistance to the flu?
mode.3:
All of these?
You must have the flu really bad.

Discuss further?
mode.4: You will need an antihistamine.
mode.5: Selection require a decongestant.
mode.6: Selection require a pain / fever reducer.
mode.7: Need an expectorant with or a cough suppressant.
mode.8: Need to quiet down the stomach.
mode.9: Need a decongestant and pain / fever medication based on your selection.
mode.10: Symptoms require an antihistamine and a pain / fever reliever.
mode.11: Selection require an expectorant with or cough suppressant and pain / fever reducer.
mode.12: Selection require stomach and pain / fever relief aids.
mode.13: Need an antihistamine and a decongestant.
mode.14: Selection require antihistamine and an expectorant with or cough suppressant.
mode.15: Symptoms require an antihistamine and stomach relief medications.
mode.16: Need a decongestant and an expectorant with or cough suppressant.
mode.17: A decongestant and stomach relief medications are required.
mode.18: Will need an expectorant with or cough suppressant and a stomach relief medication.
mode.19: Symptoms require an antihistamine, decongestant and a pain / fever reducer.
mode.20: Need an antihistamine, expectorant with or cough suppressant and a pain / fever reducer.
mode.21: Selection require an antihistamine, stomach relief and pain / fever reducer.
mode.22: Need a pain / fever reducer, decongestant, expectorant with or cough suppressant relief.
mode.23: Selection require a decongestant, stomach and pain / fever relief medications.
mode.24: Need a pain / fever, stomach and expectorant with or cough suppressant medications.
mode.25: Symptoms require a decongestant, expectorant with or cough suppressant and stomach relief medications.
mode.26: Will need an antihistamine, expectorant with or cough suppressant and stomach relief medications.
mode.27: Will need an antihistamine, decongestant and an expectorant / cough suppressant medicatons.
mode.28: Selection require an antihistamine, decongestant and stomach relief medications.
mode.29: Need an antihistamine, decongestant, pain / fever and stomach relief medications.
mode.30: Need an antihistamine, decongestant, expectorant with or cough suppressant and pain / fever relief medications.
mode.31: Need an antihistamine, stomach relief, Pain / fever with expectorant / cough suppressant medications.
mode.32: Symptoms require a decongestant, stomach, pain / fever and expectorant with or cough suppressant relief medications.
mode.33: Need an antihistamine, decongestant, stomach an expectorant with or cough suppressant medications.
mode.34:
Okay.
You must have this flu pretty bad.

mode_not.content1: Last updated by pharmacist on 01/23/2016 at 01:50:pm
mode_not.content2: You can compare over the counter multi-symptom cold and flu medications that will work best for you.

collapsable.title: Docosanol click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
This act by blocking the herpes Simplex Virus from entering the skin cells where it can replicate.

The result is cold sore with lesser symptoms, severity and shorter duration.

When used at the first sign, the tingling stage, it may shorten healing time by about a day or two. The key is using it early. The later, the less effective.

Example Abreva®

collapsable.title: Pain relieving creams click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Camphor, benzyl alcohol, phenol, thymol, menthol, benzocaine, lidocaine.

These are pain relief ingredients commonly used in cold sore formulations. They are basically numbing agents.

Numbing the area will reduce itching and pain associated with the damaged skin of the lips.

collapsable.title: Skin protectants click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Zinc oxide, allantoin, petroleum jelly.

They help keep the area moist and prevent cracking which can lead to pain.

They also act as a barrier to protect the skin and lips from external irritants.

They are useful during the scabbing stage to make scabs less likely to crack and bleed.

collapsable.title: Pain relief +  protectants click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Anbesol cold sore therapy®, Orajel single dose®.

The goal of these products is to combine pain relief with lip protection. This should make you comfortable enough to at least not be too aware of the cold sore while it is healing on its own.

collapsable.title: Antiseptics click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Benzalkonium chloride. This will help prevent a secondary bacterial infection of the affected area speeding up healing time. Usually, when your skin barrier is broken, bacteria is already diving in to do some damage. This will make the damaged skin worse quickly.

Using benzalkonium chloride will act to reduce the level and risk of bacterial infection.

collapsable.title: Antiseptics + pain relievers click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Bactine® (lidocaine + benzalkonium). This combination is actually very useful in cold sores. The combination of numbing, anti-itch, antiseptic, pain relief reduces your awareness of the cold sore, reduces the urge to touch the area, and not disturbing the cold sore makes it heal faster.

We strongly recommend you add this to your treatment regimen especially at the blistering stages.

collapsable.title: Lemon balm click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Lip balms containing 1% lemon extract shorten the healing time, prevent it from spreading and reduce recurrences.

Example Cold sore relief®

collapsable.title: Lysine click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Increase lysine intake to replace the arginine on skin cells thereby depriving the virus of arginine needed for replication. The virus needs arginine found in the skin to replicate while lysine helps deplete the skin of arginine by competing with its affinity for skin cells.

If you are prone to cold sores, you may want to make this a daily vitamin or start taking it when you feel something is coming on.

collapsable.title: Others click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
• Red eyes relief eye drops:
    To take the red out of cold sores on the skin. Use this if you want to reduce people noticing the cold sore which we all do anyway.
     
  • Ice
     
  • Non-Steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDS)
     
  • Hydrocortisone 1% cream:
    For the inflammation. Use in extreme cases of inflammation. It may delay healing time.

irregular.content:
Last updated by pharmacist on : 02/02/2016

 

Let's use this information to choose a good over the counter remedy to help with this cold sore.

tabs.header_iregular:
Canker sores are not contagious and will go away on its own.

But it may take anywhere from 7 to 10 days or sometimes up to 3 weeks before they disappear.

Until then, we will use over the counter measures to take care of the pain, speed healing and prevent any infection.

Here are a few of the self care options available to take care of canker sore.

See which will work best for your situation.
tabs.header:
Are you looking for a one time process of removing ear wax?

May be you just want to get it over with.

collapsable.title: Pain relief click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Benzocaine:

To numb the sore and reduce pain. But it wears off after a few hours.

The best approach, apply ice to the sore for a few minutes, then apply the benzocaine gel.

Prefer gel over solution for longer effect.

collapsable.title: Speed healing click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
Carbamide peroxide 10%

  • Removes unhealthy tissue 
  • cleanse and soothe
  • speeds up natural healing.
     

Milk of Magnesia

Daub milk of magnesia on the affected area and surrounding.


Benadryl + Maalox/Mylanta

Swiss and spit with equal parts of Benadryl and Maalox.


Baking soda paste

Make a paste of baking soda and water.
Daub the paste over the canker sore with a Q-tip and let it dry.

collapsable.title: Canker cover click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
May benefit a few people. But may:

  • leave a sticky mess in your mouth
  • make canker sore bigger initially
  • create a burning sensation that can last for a long time
  • irritate the gums
  • affect the teeth because it may end up sticking to the teeth rather than the sore
  • hard to take off

For these  reasons we do not recommend it if you have not tried it before.

collapsable.title: Worth trying click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
• Powdered alum on the sore.
     
  • Allow peppermint Altoids to dissolve on the sore.
    Better than using canker cover actually.
     
  • Take cimetidine 200 mg three times a day.

collapsable.title: Prevention click to expand contents
collapsable.content:
If it occurs frequently, you can try these for prevention:

  • Lysine 500 mg daily.
     
  • Vitamin B12 1000 mcg daily.
     
  • Propolis 500 mg daily.
     
  • Avoid toothpaste with sodium laurel sulfate.    
    Use Sensodyne, TheraBreath, Biotene, Rembrandt instead.

irregular.content: Last updated by pharmacist on : 02/01/2016 at 08:34:pm
